lessonQuiz.question: What is the main reason why one should invest?

options.text: To fight inflation and create wealth

lessonQuiz.answerText: To fight inflation and create wealth

lessonQuiz.question: Which asset class is considered the safest for investment?
Which of the following is NOT an example of a fixed income instrument?
Which asset class has historically generated the highest returns over the long term?
What is the term used to describe the technique of allocating money across different asset classes?
Which of the following is a key principle of investing?

options.text: Don't put all your eggs in one basket

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of a sovereign gold bond?

options.text: To provide investors with exposure to gold
To raise funds for government projects

lesson: 2. Regulators, the guardians of capital markets

lessonQuiz.question: What is the primary purpose of the stock market?

options.text: To provide a platform for companies to raise capital
To facilitate the buying and selling of shares
To regulate the trading activities of market participants
To protect the interests of investors

lessonQuiz.answerText: To facilitate the buying and selling of shares

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of SEBI?

options.text: Promoting the development of stock exchanges
Protecting the interests of retail investors
Setting and enforcing regulations for market participants

lessonQuiz.question: What is the role of Depository Participants?

options.text: To hold and manage securities for investors
To provide access to trading platforms
To regulate the activities of stockbrokers
To issue new shares to the public

lessonQuiz.answerText: To hold and manage securities for investors

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is a type of market participant?
What is the purpose of a Debenture Trustee?

options.text: To issue debentures on behalf of companies
To act as a custodian of debenture holders' interests
To provide credit ratings for debentures
To regulate the trading of debentures

lessonQuiz.answerText: To act as a custodian of debenture holders' interests

lessonQuiz.question: What is the main concern of the stock market regulator?

options.text: Ensuring the stability of the market

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is a key takeaway from the chapter?

options.text: The stock market is only accessible by large corporations
SEBI has no authority over the stock market
Market participants are free to engage in any activity they wish
All entities operating in the market must comply with SEBI regulations

lessonQuiz.answerText: All entities operating in the market must comply with SEBI regulations

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a service provided by a stockbroker?
What is the term for the digital format of a share certificate?
Who is the intermediary between a depository and an account holder?
What is the primary purpose of a clearing corporation?

options.text: To act as a market maker

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a factor to consider when selecting a stockbroker?
What is the name of Zerodha's trading platform?
What is the term for the digital storage place for share certificates?
Who is referred to as an angel investor?

options.text: A person who provides seed funding to a company
A venture capitalist who invests in early-stage companies
A private equity investor who invests in mature companies
A bank that provides loans to companies

lessonQuiz.answerText: A person who provides seed funding to a company

lessonQuiz.question: What is the term used to describe a company's initial funding from friends and family?
Which type of investor typically invests in companies that have a proven track record and are looking to expand?
What is the purpose of an initial public offering (IPO)?

options.text: To raise funds from the general public

lessonQuiz.answerText: To raise funds from the general public

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of an IPO?

options.text: It is the first time a company's shares are offered to the public
It is typically used to raise small amounts of capital
It is not regulated by the government

lessonQuiz.answerText: It is the first time a company's shares are offered to the public

lessonQuiz.question: What is the main reason most companies go public?

options.text: To raise funds to fuel their CAPEX requirement
To provide an exit for early-stage investors
To take advantage of tax benefits

lessonQuiz.answerText: To raise funds to fuel their CAPEX requirement

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a responsibility of a merchant banker in the IPO process?

options.text: Conducting due diligence on the company
Helping the company prepare its listing documents

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of the DRHP?

options.text: To provide potential investors with detailed information about the company
To outline the company's business plan and financial projections
To secure regulatory approval for the IPO
To promote the IPO to the public

lessonQuiz.answerText: To provide potential investors with detailed information about the company

lessonQuiz.question: What is the process called where the company collects price points and respective quantities from potential investors?
What is the term for the day when a company's stock starts trading publicly on the stock exchange?
What is the term for when an IPO fails to attract enough subscriptions from investors?
What is the role of a Green Shoe Option in an IPO?

options.text: To stabilize the stock price after the IPO
To give the underwriters the option to purchase additional shares
To raise additional funds for the company

lessonQuiz.answerText: To give the underwriters the option to purchase additional shares

lessonQuiz.question: What is the primary job of a stock market?

options.text: To regulate the sale and purchase of stocks
To provide companies with a platform to raise funds
To facilitate transactions between buyers and sellers of stocks
To protect investors from fraudulent activities

lessonQuiz.answerText: To facilitate transactions between buyers and sellers of stocks

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a reason why stock prices move?
What is the difference between a trader and an investor?

options.text: Traders hold stocks for long periods, while investors trade stocks frequently
Traders seek to profit from short-term price movements, while investors focus on long-term growth
Traders are more risk-averse than investors
There is no difference between traders and investors

lessonQuiz.answerText: Traders seek to profit from short-term price movements, while investors focus on long-term growth

lessonQuiz.question: Which type of trader typically holds stocks for the shortest period of time?
Which type of investor focuses on identifying companies with high growth potential?
What is the formula for calculating absolute return?
What is a key difference between absolute return and CAGR?

options.text: Absolute return considers the time period, while CAGR does not
CAGR considers the time period, while absolute return does not
Absolute return is expressed as a percentage, while CAGR is not
There is no difference between absolute return and CAGR

lessonQuiz.answerText: CAGR considers the time period, while absolute return does not

lessonQuiz.question: What is the primary function of a stock market index?

options.text: To represent the overall trend of the market
To track the performance of individual companies
To provide information on stock prices

lessonQuiz.answerText: To represent the overall trend of the market

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a popular index in India?
What method is used to assign weights to stocks in the Nifty 50 index?
Which of the following is a practical use of the index?
What is the purpose of portfolio hedging using the index?

options.text: To reduce risk during market downturns

lessonQuiz.answerText: To reduce risk during market downturns

lessonQuiz.question: What is the full form of S&P in the context of stock market indices?
Which of the following sectors is NOT represented by a heavyweight stock in the Nifty 50 index?
Which of the following refers to the lowest price a stock has traded at within the last 52 weeks?
What is the term for a trading position you initiate with an expectation to close the position within the same day?
Which market segment deals with fixed-income securities?
What does it mean to "square off" a trading position?

options.text: To close the position by selling the stock
To close the position by buying the stock
To open a new position in the same stock
To reverse the direction of the original position

lessonQuiz.answerText: To close the position by buying the stock

lessonQuiz.question: What is the name of the price band within which a stock can be traded on a given trading day?
If you are bearish on a stock, what do you expect to happen to its price?
What is the term for a trading strategy in which you sell a stock first and then buy it back later at a lower price?
What are the three methods of placing a transaction in the stock market?

options.text: Call your brokerage, use a web application, or use a mobile application
Use a web application or a mobile application
Call your brokerage or use a web application
Use a mobile application or call your brokerage

lessonQuiz.answerText:
Call your stocks broker (usually on the central support number), and request to buy or sell a stock; this is called “Call & Trade.”

Use a web application

Use a mobile application

lessonQuiz.question: What is the name of Zerodha's trading terminal?
What is the purpose of the market watch?

options.text: To display the last traded price, percentage change, and other relevant information about a stock
To allow you to place buy and sell orders
To track the status of your orders
To view charts and technical indicators

lessonQuiz.answerText: To display the last traded price, percentage change, and other relevant information about a stock

lessonQuiz.question: What is the difference between a limit order and a market order?

options.text: A limit order is executed at a specific price, while a market order is executed at the best available price
A market order is executed at a specific price, while a limit order is executed at the best available price
Limit orders and market orders are both executed at the same price
Market orders are executed immediately, while limit orders are executed over time

lessonQuiz.answerText: A limit order is executed at a specific price, while a market order is executed at the best available price

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of a stop-loss order?

options.text: To protect against losses by automatically selling a stock if it falls below a certain price
To automatically buy a stock if it rises above a certain price
To place a limit order at a specific price
To track the status of an order

lessonQuiz.answerText: To protect against losses by automatically selling a stock if it falls below a certain price

lessonQuiz.question: What information is contained in the order book?

options.text: Current status of all open orders

lessonQuiz.answerText: Current status of all open orders

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of the trade book?

options.text: To track the history of all completed orders
To display the current status of open orders
To place buy and sell orders
To view bid and offer prices

lessonQuiz.answerText: To track the history of all completed orders

lessonQuiz.question: What are the bid and offer prices?

options.text: The prices at which buyers and sellers are willing to trade
The highest and lowest prices at which a stock has traded in the past day
The prices at which a stock is currently being bought and sold
The prices at which a stock is expected to open and close at the end of the day

lessonQuiz.answerText: The prices at which buyers and sellers are willing to trade

lessonQuiz.question: What is the day you make a transaction called?
What is the name of the document that details all daily transactions?
When are shares reflected in the purchaser's DEMAT account?
On what day are all equity/stock settlements in India made?
What is the purpose of earmarking in the context of selling shares?

options.text: To ensure the securities don't move out of the client's demat account
To allow brokers to hold client shares in their pool account
To speed up the settlement process

lessonQuiz.answerText: To ensure the securities don't move out of the client's demat account

lessonQuiz.question: What percentage of funds do sellers receive on T day?
When are the remaining 20% of funds received by sellers after T day?

lesson: 11. Corporate actions and impact on stock prices

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is a type of corporate action that involves paying a portion of profits to shareholders on a per-share basis?
What is the purpose of a bonus issue?

options.text: To raise capital from existing shareholders
To increase the number of shares outstanding without changing the total value
To decrease the market price of a stock
To reduce the face value of the stock

lessonQuiz.answerText: To increase the number of shares outstanding without changing the total value

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following statements about stock splits is true?

options.text: The face value of the stock remains unchanged
The number of shares outstanding increases

lessonQuiz.question: What is a rights issue?

options.text: An opportunity for existing shareholders to purchase new shares at a discount
A way for the company to pay off debt

lessonQuiz.answerText: An opportunity for existing shareholders to purchase new shares at a discount

lessonQuiz.question: What is the purpose of a share buyback?

options.text: To reduce the number of shares outstanding

lessonQuiz.answerText: To reduce the number of shares outstanding

lesson: 12. Key Events and Their Impact on Markets

lessonQuiz.question: What is the central bank of India?
What is the purpose of monetary policy?
What is the relationship between interest rates and inflation?

options.text: High interest rates lead to low inflation
Low interest rates lead to low inflation
High interest rates lead to high inflation
Low interest rates lead to high inflation

lessonQuiz.answerText: High interest rates lead to low inflation

lessonQuiz.question: What is the Index of Industrial Production (IIP)?

options.text: A measure of industrial production in India
A measure of inflation in India
A measure of consumer spending in India
A measure of GDP growth in India

lessonQuiz.answerText: A measure of industrial production in India

lessonQuiz.question: What is the Purchasing Managers Index (PMI)?

options.text: A survey-based indicator of business activity

lessonQuiz.answerText: A survey-based indicator of business activity

lessonQuiz.question: What is the importance of corporate earnings announcements?

options.text: They provide information about the financial health of a company
They can lead to changes in stock prices
They can help investors make informed investment decisions

lessonQuiz.question: What is a non-financial event that can impact the markets?
1) Which of the following is considered the most important factor for success in the markets?
2) Which of the following is NOT a method used to develop a point of view in the markets?
3) Which of the following is the most reliable source of trading advice?
4) Which of the following is NOT a trading instrument that can be used to complement a bullish point of view?
5) Which of the following is the purpose of risk management in trading?
6) What is the first step in developing a trading plan?
7) What is a stop-loss order?

options.text: An order to buy a stock at a specific price
An order to sell a stock at a specific price
An order to automatically sell a stock if it falls below a certain price
An order to automatically buy a stock if it rises above a certain price

lessonQuiz.answerText: An order to automatically sell a stock if it falls below a certain price

lessonQuiz.question: What is the main reason for a company to go public through an IPO?

options.text: To raise capital for expansion or cash out investors

lessonQuiz.answerText: To raise capital for expansion or cash out investors

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of an OFS?

options.text: Shares are offered to the entire market

lessonQuiz.question: What is the primary difference between an FPO and an IPO?

options.text: FPOs involve the sale of new shares while IPOs involve the sale of existing shares
IPOs are used to raise capital for new projects while FPOs are used to raise capital for existing projects
FPOs require SEBI approval while IPOs do not
IPOs are only available to large companies while FPOs are available to all listed companies

lessonQuiz.answerText: FPOs involve the sale of new shares while IPOs involve the sale of existing shares

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is a benefit of an OFS compared to an FPO?

options.text: OFS has a faster approval process
OFS allows for greater flexibility in pricing
OFS is less dilutive to existing shareholders
OFS is more transparent than FPO

lessonQuiz.answerText: OFS has a faster approval process

lessonQuiz.question: What is the main purpose of a rights issue?

options.text: To award existing shareholders with free shares
To raise additional capital from existing shareholders
To dilute the shareholdings of specific investors
To increase the liquidity of the company's shares

lessonQuiz.answerText: To raise additional capital from existing shareholders

lesson: 15. Supplementary note – The 20 market depth or level 3 data

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a feature of the 20 Market Depth (level 3 data) Window?
How can the 20 Market Depth Window assist in determining a stop-loss price?

options.text: By identifying concentrations of bids or offers at specific price levels
By providing real-time updates on market volatility
By connecting the user to a real-time chat with other traders

lessonQuiz.answerText: By identifying concentrations of bids or offers at specific price levels

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is an advantage of the 20 Market Depth feature for option traders?

options.text: It provides greater visibility into contract availability
It guarantees execution at the best possible price
It eliminates the risk of slippage

lessonQuiz.answerText: It provides greater visibility into contract availability

lessonQuiz.question: How can the 20 Market Depth Window help traders validate the support and resistance levels?

options.text: By comparing the order book data with the price chart
By using the order book data to create statistical models
By displaying real-time alerts when support or resistance levels are breached
By connecting the user to a team of analysts who provide support and resistance levels

lessonQuiz.answerText: By comparing the order book data with the price chart

lessonQuiz.question: Which of the following is a drawback of the 20 Market Depth Window?

options.text: It can be overwhelming for new traders
It only displays data from a single exchange
It is not available on all trading platforms
It is subject to frequent data lags

lessonQuiz.answerText: It can be overwhelming for new traders
